title: Authors and Citation
text: Csárdi G (2026). tstoml: Edit TOML files. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://github.com/gaborcsardi/tstoml.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tstoml: Edit TOML files},   author = {Gábor Csárdi},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://github.com/gaborcsardi/tstoml}, }

title: Edit TOML files
text: Extract manipulate parts TOML files without touching formatting comments parts.

title: Edit TOML files
text: can install development version tstoml GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("gaborcsardi/tstoml")

title: Edit TOML files
text: See https://gaborcsardi.github.io/tstoml/ also installed package: help(package = "tstoml").

title: Edit TOML files
text: Create tstoml object string: Pretty print tstoml object:
code: txt <- r"( # This is a TOML document  title = "TOML Example"  [owner] name = "Tom Preston-Werner" dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00  [database] enabled = true ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 }  [servers]  [servers.alpha] ip = "10.0.0.1" role = "frontend"  [servers.beta] ip = "10.0.0.2" role = "backend" )" toml <- ts_parse_toml(text = txt) toml #> # toml (24 lines) #>  1 |  #>  2 | # This is a TOML document #>  3 |  #>  4 | title = "TOML Example" #>  5 |  #>  6 | [owner] #>  7 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  8 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  9 |  #> 10 | [database] #> ℹ 14 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines

what: Select elements in a tstoml object
title: Edit TOML files
text: Select element(s) inside elements: Select element(s) array: Select multiple keys table:
code: ts_tree_select(toml, "owner") #> # toml (24 lines, 1 selected element) #>   ... #>    3  |  #>    4  | title = "TOML Example" #>    5  |  #> >  6  | [owner] #> >  7  | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #> >  8  | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #> >  9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   11  | enabled = true #>   12  | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #>   ... ts_tree_select(toml, "owner", "name") #> # toml (24 lines, 1 selected element) #>   ... #>    4  | title = "TOML Example" #>    5  |  #>    6  | [owner] #> >  7  | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>    8  | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>    9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   ... ts_tree_select(toml, "database", "ports", 1:2) #> # toml (24 lines, 2 selected elements) #>   ... #>    9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   11  | enabled = true #> > 12  | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #>   13  | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #>   14  | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #>   15  |  #>   ... ts_tree_select(toml, "owner", c("name", "dob")) #> # toml (24 lines, 2 selected elements) #>   ... #>    4  | title = "TOML Example" #>    5  |  #>    6  | [owner] #> >  7  | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #> >  8  | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>    9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   11  | enabled = true #>   ...

title: Edit TOML files
text: Delete selected elements:
code: ts_tree_select(toml, "owner", "name") |> ts_tree_delete() #> # toml (22 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  7 |  #>  8 | [database] #>  9 | enabled = true #> 10 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #> ℹ 12 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines

title: Edit TOML files
text: Insert key-value pair document: Insert key-value pair table: Insert element array: Insert new table document: Insert new array tables document:
code: ts_tree_insert(toml, key = "new_key", "new_value") #> # toml (25 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 |  #>  6 | new_key = "new_value" #>  7 | [owner] #>  8 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  9 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #> 10 |  #> ℹ 15 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines ts_tree_select(toml, "owner") |> ts_tree_insert(key = "dpt", "Engineering") #> # toml (24 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 | dpt = "Engineering" #>  9 |  #> 10 | [database] #> ℹ 14 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines ts_tree_select(toml, "database", "ports") |>   ts_tree_insert(10000L) |>   print(n = 100) #> # toml (23 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 |  #>  9 | [database] #> 10 | enabled = true #> 11 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002, 10000 ] #> 12 | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #> 13 | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #> 14 |  #> 15 | [servers] #> 16 |  #> 17 | [servers.alpha] #> 18 | ip = "10.0.0.1" #> 19 | role = "frontend" #> 20 |  #> 21 | [servers.beta] #> 22 | ip = "10.0.0.2" #> 23 | role = "backend" ts_tree_insert(toml, key = "new_table", list(a = 1, b = 2)) |>   print(n = 100) #> # toml (27 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 |  #>  9 | [database] #> 10 | enabled = true #> 11 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #> 12 | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #> 13 | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #> 14 |  #> 15 | [servers] #> 16 |  #> 17 | [servers.alpha] #> 18 | ip = "10.0.0.1" #> 19 | role = "frontend" #> 20 |  #> 21 | [servers.beta] #> 22 | ip = "10.0.0.2" #> 23 | role = "backend" #> 24 |  #> 25 | [new_table] #> 26 | a = 1.0 #> 27 | b = 2.0 ts_tree_insert(toml, key = "new_aot",   list(list(x = 1), list(x = 2))) |>   print(n = 100) #> # toml (29 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 |  #>  9 | [database] #> 10 | enabled = true #> 11 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #> 12 | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #> 13 | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #> 14 |  #> 15 | [servers] #> 16 |  #> 17 | [servers.alpha] #> 18 | ip = "10.0.0.1" #> 19 | role = "frontend" #> 20 |  #> 21 | [servers.beta] #> 22 | ip = "10.0.0.2" #> 23 | role = "backend" #> 24 |  #> 25 | [[new_aot]] #> 26 | x = 1.0 #> 27 |  #> 28 | [[new_aot]] #> 29 | x = 2.0

title: Edit TOML files
text: Update existing element: Update multiple elements :
code: ts_tree_select(toml, "title") |> ts_tree_update("A New TOML Example") #> # toml (23 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "A New TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 |  #>  9 | [database] #> 10 | enabled = true #> ℹ 13 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines ts_tree_select(toml, "servers", c("alpha", "beta"), "ip") |>   ts_tree_update("192.168.1.23") |>   print(n = 100) #> # toml (23 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 |  #>  9 | [database] #> 10 | enabled = true #> 11 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #> 12 | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #> 13 | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #> 14 |  #> 15 | [servers] #> 16 |  #> 17 | [servers.alpha] #> 18 | ip = "192.168.1.23" #> 19 | role = "frontend" #> 20 |  #> 21 | [servers.beta] #> 22 | ip = "192.168.1.23" #> 23 | role = "backend"

text: Create tstoml object string:   Pretty print tstoml object:
code: txt <- r"( # This is a TOML document  title = "TOML Example"  [owner] name = "Tom Preston-Werner" dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00  [database] enabled = true ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 }  [servers]  [servers.alpha] ip = "10.0.0.1" role = "frontend"  [servers.beta] ip = "10.0.0.2" role = "backend" )" toml <- ts_parse_toml(text = txt) toml #> # toml (24 lines) #>  1 |  #>  2 | # This is a TOML document #>  3 |  #>  4 | title = "TOML Example" #>  5 |  #>  6 | [owner] #>  7 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  8 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  9 |  #> 10 | [database] #> ℹ 14 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines

code: writeLines(toml_example_text()) #> # This is a TOML document #>  #> title = "TOML Example" #>  #> [owner] #> name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #> dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  #> [database] #> enabled = true #> ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #> data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #> temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #>  #> [servers] #>  #> [servers.alpha] #> ip = "10.0.0.1" #> role = "frontend" #>  #> [servers.beta] #> ip = "10.0.0.2" #> role = "backend" #>

title: Format a TOML file — ts_format_toml
text: Format TOML file

title: Format a TOML file — ts_format_toml
code: ts_format_toml(file = NULL, text = NULL, options = NULL)

title: Format a TOML file — ts_format_toml
text: file Path TOML file. Use one file text. text TOML content raw vector character vector. Use one file text. options Named list parsing formatting options, see tstoml options.

what: Parse a TOML file or string into a ts_tree_toml object — ts_parse_toml
title: Parse a TOML file or string into a ts_tree_toml object — ts_parse_toml
text: Parse TOML file string ts_tree_toml object

title: Parse a TOML file or string into a ts_tree_toml object — ts_parse_toml
code: ts_parse_toml(text, ranges = NULL, fail_on_parse_error = TRUE, options = NULL)  ts_read_toml(file, ranges = NULL, fail_on_parse_error = TRUE, options = NULL)

title: Parse a TOML file or string into a ts_tree_toml object — ts_parse_toml
text: text String parse. Use either file text, . ranges Can used parse part(s) input. must data frame integer columns start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col, start_byte, end_byte, order. fail_on_parse_error Logical, whether error parse errors document. Default TRUE. options Named list parsing options, see tstoml options. file Path file parse. Use either file text, .

title: Parse a TOML file or string into a ts_tree_toml object — ts_parse_toml
text: ts_tree_toml object.

what: Serialize an R object to TOML — ts_serialize_toml
title: Serialize an R object to TOML — ts_serialize_toml
text: Create TOML R object. Note function generic serializer can represent R object TOML. Also, expect ts_unserialize_toml() exact inverse ts_serialize_toml().

title: Serialize an R object to TOML — ts_serialize_toml
code: ts_serialize_toml(obj, file = NULL, collapse = FALSE, options = NULL)  ts_toml_table(...)  ts_toml_inline_table(...)  ts_toml_array(...)  ts_toml_array_of_tables(...)

title: Serialize an R object to TOML — ts_serialize_toml
text: obj R object serialize. file NULL result written file. collapse file NULL whether return character scalar character vector. options named list tstoml options, see tstoml_options(). ... Elements TOML table, array, inline table array tables.

title: Serialize an R object to TOML — ts_serialize_toml
text: file NULL character scalar (collapse = TRUE) vector (collapse = FALSE). file NULL nothing.

title: Serialize an R object to TOML — ts_serialize_toml
text: See examples create possible TOML elements ts_serialize_toml(). Use ts_toml_table() make list serialized TOML table. named lists serialized TOML tables default, readability. Use ts_toml_inline_table() make list serialized inline TOML table. default named lists serialized regular TOML tables, possible. Use ts_toml_array() make list serialized TOML array. default un-named lists serialized arrays, unless lists named lists (serialized arrays tables). Use funtion mark list serialized array. Use ts_toml_array_of_tables() make list serialized TOML array tables. must list named lists. default lists named lists serialized arrays tables, readability.

title: Serialize a TOML value — ts_serialize_toml_value
text: Serialize TOML value

title: Serialize a TOML value — ts_serialize_toml_value
code: ts_serialize_toml_value(obj, options = NULL)

title: Serialize a TOML value — ts_serialize_toml_value
text: obj R object serialize TOML value. options named list tstoml options, see tstoml_options().

text: Modified tstoml object.

title: Delete selected elements from a tstoml object — ts_tree_delete.ts_tree_toml
text: toml selection whole document deleted. toml empty selection, nothing delted.

title: Delete selected elements from a tstoml object — ts_tree_delete.ts_tree_toml
code: library(ts) toml <- ts_parse_toml(text = toml_example_text()) toml #> # toml (23 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  7 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  8 |  #>  9 | [database] #> 10 | enabled = true #> ℹ 13 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines  toml |> ts_tree_select("owner", "name") |> ts_tree_delete() #> # toml (22 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [owner] #>  6 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  7 |  #>  8 | [database] #>  9 | enabled = true #> 10 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #> ℹ 12 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines toml |> ts_tree_select("owner") |> ts_tree_delete() #> # toml (19 lines) #>  1 | # This is a TOML document #>  2 |  #>  3 | title = "TOML Example" #>  4 |  #>  5 | [database] #>  6 | enabled = true #>  7 | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #>  8 | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #>  9 | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #> 10 |  #> ℹ 9 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines

title: Run tree-sitter queries on TOML tree-sitter trees — ts_tree_query.ts_tree_toml

title: Run tree-sitter queries on TOML tree-sitter trees — ts_tree_query.ts_tree_toml
text: tree ts_tree object. query Character string, tree-sitter query run.

title: Run tree-sitter queries on TOML tree-sitter trees — ts_tree_query.ts_tree_toml
text: list entries patterns matched_captures. patterns contains information patterns queries data frame columns: id, name, pattern, match_count. matched_captures contains information matches, columns id, pattern, match, start_byte, end_byte, start_row, start_column, end_row, end_column, name, code. pattern column matched_captured refers id column patterns.

title: Run tree-sitter queries on TOML tree-sitter trees — ts_tree_query.ts_tree_toml
text: probably need know details specific tree-sitter parser using, write effective queries. See documentation parser package using details node types query language support. See links .   function openCity(evt, language) {   var currentTab = evt.srcElement.parentElement.parentElement;   var , x, tablinks;   x = currentTab.getElementsByClassName("ts-package");   (= 0; < x.length; ++) {     x[].style.display = "none";   }   tablinks = currentTab.getElementsByClassName("tablink");   (= 0; < x.length; ++) {     tablinks[].className = tablinks[].className.replace(" w3-active", "");   }   currentTab.getElementsByClassName("ts-package-" + language)[0].style.display = "block";   evt.srcElement.className += " w3-active"; }  .w3-container:, .w3-container:, .w3-panel:, .w3-panel:, .w3-row:, .w3-row:, .w3-row-padding:, .w3-row-padding:, .w3-cell-row:, .w3-cell-row:, .w3-clear:, .w3-clear:, .w3-bar:, .w3-bar:{   content:"";   display: table;   clear: }.w3-container, .w3-panel {   padding: 0.01em 16px }.w3-panel {   margin-top: 16px;   margin-bottom: 16px }.w3-bar {   width: 100%;   overflow: hidden }.w3-center .w3-bar {   display: inline-block;   width: auto }.w3-bar .w3-bar-item {   padding: 8px 16px;   float: left;   width: auto;   border: none;   display: block;   outline: 0 }.w3-bar .w3-button {   white-space: normal;   border: 1px solid; }.w3-block {   display: block;   width: 100% }.w3-btn, .w3-button {   border: none;   display: inline-block;   padding: 8px 16px;   vertical-align: middle;   overflow: hidden;   text-decoration: none;   color: inherit;   background-color: inherit;   text-align: center;   cursor: pointer;   white-space: nowrap }.w3-btn, .w3-button{   -webkit-touch-callout: none;   -webkit-user-select: none;   -khtml-user-select: none;   -moz-user-select: none;   -ms-user-select: none;   user-select: none }.w3-bar .w3-button {   white-space: normal }.w3-button:hover {   color: #000!important;   background-color: #ccc!important }.w3-active, .w3-hover-active:hover {   background-color: #aaa;   color: #000; }.w3-border-0 {   border: 0!important }.w3-border {   border: 1px solid #ccc!important;   margin-bottom: 10px; }.w3-border-top {   border-top: 1px solid #ccc!important }.w3-border-bottom {   border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc!important }.w3-border-left {   border-left: 1px solid #ccc!important }.w3-border-right{   border-right: 1px solid #ccc!important }/* undo gradient tidytemplate, add whole tab */ .ts-package {   background-image: linear-gradient(-160deg, #f8f8f8 0, #f1f1f1 100%);   margin-bottom: 10px; } .ts-package pre, code {   background-image: none;   background-color: #00000000; }

title: Run tree-sitter queries on TOML tree-sitter trees — ts_tree_query.ts_tree_toml
code:
# Select all numbers in a TOML document ------------------------------------ library(ts) toml <- tstoml::ts_parse_toml(   'a = 1
b = [10.0, 20, 30]
c = { c1 = true, c2 = 100 }' ) toml |> ts_tree_query("[(float) (integer)] @number") #> $patterns #> # A data frame: 1 × 4 #>      id name  pattern                         match_count #>   <int> <chr> <chr>                                 <int> #> 1     1 NA    "[(float) (integer)] @number
"           5 #>  #> $captures #> # A data frame: 1 × 2 #>      id name   #>   <int> <chr>  #> 1     1 number #>  #> $matched_captures #> # A data frame: 5 × 12 #>      id pattern match type   start_byte end_byte start_row start_column #>   <int>   <int> <int> <chr>       <int>    <int>     <int>        <int> #> 1     1       1     1 integ…          4        5         0            4 #> 2     1       1     2 float          11       15         1            5 #> 3     1       1     3 integ…         17       19         1           11 #> 4     1       1     4 integ…         21       23         1           15 #> 5     1       1     5 integ…         47       50         2           22 #> # ℹ 4 more variables: end_row <int>, end_column <int>, name <chr>, #> #   code <chr> #>

what: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: function heart ts. edit tree-sitter tree, first need select parts want delete update. S3 method ts::ts_tree_select() generic, tstoml objects.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
code: # S3 method for class 'tstoml' ts_tree_select(tree, ..., refine = FALSE)

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: tree ts_tree object returned ts_tree_new(). ... Selection expressions, see details. refine Logical, whether refine current selection start new selection.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: ts_tree object selected parts.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: selection process iterative. Selection expressions (selectors) applied one one, selector selects nodes currently selected nodes. selector, applied individually currently selected node, results concatenated. selection process starts root DOM tree, document node (see ts_tree_dom()), unless refine = TRUE set, case starts current selection. See various types selection expressions .

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: Selects child nodes current nodes.
code: toml <- tstoml::ts_parse_toml('   a = 1   b = [10, 20, 30]   [c]   c1 = true   c2 = [] ') toml |> ts_tree_select(c("b", "c"), TRUE) #> # toml (6 lines, 5 selected elements) #>   1 |  #>   2 |   a = 1 #> > 3 |   b = [10, 20, 30] #>   4 |   [c] #> > 5 |   c1 = true #> > 6 |   c2 = []

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: Selects child nodes given names nodes named children. node named children, selects nothing node.
code: toml <- tstoml::ts_parse_toml('   a = 1   b = [10, 20, 30]   [c]   c1 = true   c2 = [] ') toml |> ts_tree_select(c("a", "c"), "c1") #> # toml (6 lines, 1 selected element) #>   2 |   a = 1 #>   3 |   b = [10, 20, 30] #>   4 |   [c] #> > 5 |   c1 = true #>   6 |   c2 = []

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: Selects child nodes position. Positive indices count start, negative indices count end. Zero indices allowed.
code: toml <- tstoml::ts_parse_toml('   a = 1   b = [10, 20, 30]   [c]   c1 = true   c2 = [] ') toml |> ts_tree_select(c("b", "c"), -1) #> # toml (6 lines, 2 selected elements) #>   1 |  #>   2 |   a = 1 #> > 3 |   b = [10, 20, 30] #>   4 |   [c] #>   5 |   c1 = true #> > 6 |   c2 = []

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: character scalar named regex can used select child nodes whose names match given regular expression, nodes named children. node named children, selects nothing node.
code:
toml <- tstoml::ts_parse_toml(  'apple = 1
almond = 2
banana = 3
cherry = 4
' ) toml |> ts_tree_select(regex = "^a") #> # toml (4 lines, 2 selected elements) #> > 1 | apple = 1 #> > 2 | almond = 2 #>   3 | banana = 3 #>   4 | cherry = 4

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: character scalar named query can used select nodes matching tree-sitter query. See ts_tree_query() details tree-sitter queries.  Instead character scalar can also two-element list, first element query string second element character vector capture names select. case nodes matching given capture names selected.   See tstoml::ts_language_toml() details TOML grammar.  example selects integers TOML document.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: can use (c(...)) select nodes ids directly. advanced use cases .

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: refine argument ts_tree_select() TRUE, selection starts already selected elements (simultanously), instead starting document element.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: ts_tree_select<-() replacement function works similarly combination ts_tree_select() ts_tree_update(), might readable.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: [[ operator works similarly combination ts_tree_select() ts_tree_unserialize(), might readable.          [[<- operator works similarly combination ts_tree_select() ts_tree_update(), (also replacement function ts_tree_select<-()), might readable.

title: Select parts of a TOML tree-sitter tree — ts_tree_select.ts_tree_toml
text: Pretty print tstoml object:     Select elements tstoml object     Select element(s) inside elements:     Select element(s) array:     Select multiple keys table:
code: txt <- r"( # This is a TOML documenttitle = "TOML Example"[owner] name = "Tom Preston-Werner" dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00[database] enabled = true ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 }[servers][servers.alpha] ip = "10.0.0.1" role = "frontend"[servers.beta] ip = "10.0.0.2" role = "backend" )" toml <- ts_parse_toml(text = txt) toml #> # toml (24 lines) #>  1 |  #>  2 | # This is a TOML document #>  3 |  #>  4 | title = "TOML Example" #>  5 |  #>  6 | [owner] #>  7 | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>  8 | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>  9 |  #> 10 | [database] #> ℹ 14 more lines #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more lines ts_tree_select(toml, "owner") #> # toml (24 lines, 1 selected element) #>   ... #>    3  |  #>    4  | title = "TOML Example" #>    5  |  #> >  6  | [owner] #> >  7  | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #> >  8  | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #> >  9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   11  | enabled = true #>   12  | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #>   ... ts_tree_select(toml, "owner", "name") #> # toml (24 lines, 1 selected element) #>   ... #>    4  | title = "TOML Example" #>    5  |  #>    6  | [owner] #> >  7  | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #>    8  | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>    9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   ... ts_tree_select(toml, "database", "ports", 1:2) #> # toml (24 lines, 2 selected elements) #>   ... #>    9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   11  | enabled = true #> > 12  | ports = [ 8000, 8001, 8002 ] #>   13  | data = [ ["delta", "phi"], [3.14] ] #>   14  | temp_targets = { cpu = 79.5, case = 72.0 } #>   15  |  #>   ... ts_tree_select(toml, "owner", c("name", "dob")) #> # toml (24 lines, 2 selected elements) #>   ... #>    4  | title = "TOML Example" #>    5  |  #>    6  | [owner] #> >  7  | name = "Tom Preston-Werner" #> >  8  | dob = 1979-05-27T07:32:00-08:00 #>    9  |  #>   10  | [database] #>   11  | enabled = true #>   ...

title: Unserialize TOML to R objects — ts_unserialize_toml

title: Unserialize TOML to R objects — ts_unserialize_toml
code: ts_unserialize_toml(file = NULL, text = NULL, ranges = NULL, options = NULL)

title: Unserialize TOML to R objects — ts_unserialize_toml
text: file Path file parse. Use either file text, . text String parse. Use either file text, . ranges Can used parse part(s) input. must data frame integer columns start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col, start_byte, end_byte, order. options Named list parsing options, see tstoml options.

title: tstoml: Edit TOML files — tstoml-package
text: Extract manipulate parts TOML files without touching formatting comments parts.

title: tstoml options — tstoml_options
text: Options control behavior tstoml functions.

title: tstoml options — tstoml_options
text: indent_width: integer, number spaces use indentation indent_style "space". Default 4. indent_style: string, either "space" "tab", type indentation use. Default space.
